awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Dynamic Imaging Particle Analyzer for Characterization of Particulate Matters in Engineered and Natural Water Systems at Montclair State University
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is to purchase a Dynamic Imaging Particle Analyzer (DIPA) for research and training associated with particles in water at Montclair State University (MSU). The DIPA is capable of accurately and rapidly counting and characterizing particles in water. It will serve as a core instrument for two MSU's existing research areas: 1) the development of innovative water treatment technologies for the removal of various water pollutants and 2) the identification and characterization of algae in natural freshwater. Furthermore, the DIPA will be used to open new research opportunities for MSU, including the measurement of storm water runoff particulates related to soil erosion and the development of emergency water treatment for natural disasters. The DIPA will be shared among MSU faculty, research staff, and students across different departments and programs. The instrument will also be used for educational and outreach purposes.

Particulate matters (PMs), such as clays and algal cells, can significantly degrade the quality of engineered and natural water systems. Occasionally, PMs (e.g. flocs from coagulant addition) are intentionally produced for removing undesirable water contaminants (e.g. colloids). Accurate and rapid analyses of these PMs are key to the success of MSU's core research areas in water treatment and freshwater phytoplankton. The proposed DIPA will provide a real-time and non-invasive way to image, count, and characterize PMs in water. This instrument will enable new research opportunities for multiple programs at MSU, particularly environmental engineering, environmental science, ecology, biology, and chemistry. The instrument will also be used for the Passaic River Institute's public education on recreational water safety.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Funds from this NSF MRI project were requested for the acquisition of a Dynamic Imaging Particle Analyzer (DIPA) (FlowCAM 8400) for strengthening research, hands-on education, and analytical training across different disciplines at Montclair State University (MSU). The new DIPA instrument strongly supported our expanding research needs in water treatment and reuse, ecology, water quality, disaster resilience, environmental biology, molecular microbiology, and aquatic chemistry. Over the project duration, the DIPA has been extensively shared as a central instrumental role among MSU faculty, research staff, and students. Therefore, the project has multi-faceted outcomes.

 

Intellectual Merit: DIPA permits a real-time and non-invasive approach to imaging, counting, and characterizing particulate matters in engineered and natural water systems, essentially different from traditional particle imaging ways. It was used as a major tool in several on-going research projects to characterize metal oxide coagulation behaviors in water treatment and identify algal cells, part of which were PhD and MS students? dissertation and theses research. Meanwhile, the DIPA was applied by visiting high school students to complete their summer research intern projects. The data advances engineering and science associated with aqueous particulate matter, such as elimination of water pollutants for emerging water supply in the aftermath of natural disasters, occurrence of algal blooming in New Jersey, and biochar characterization over stormwater treatment. Besides, data obtained from the instrument were used as preliminary results in research proposals for pursuing new grant supports from federal and state agencies.

 

Broader Impact: The DIPA instrument substantially enhances the research and teaching resources for the rapidly increasing student population at MSU. It offers more research training opportunities for MSU faculty, students, staff, and visiting high school students, in particular for a unique transdisciplinary PhD program in Environmental Science and Management. The instrument and its application have been added to teaching portfolios of several graduate and undergraduate courses in two MSU?s departments, thereby allowing more students to earn hand-on education experience. Key research results presented in publications and conferences make the research widely delivered within the academic community. Equally important, this project produced a profound impact upon underrepresented groups, given that MSU is a Hispanic-Serving Institution and the visiting pre-college summer research students come from economically disadvantaged Hispanic families.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2021
Modified by: Yang Deng

Image
  • A Dynamic Imaging Particle Analyzer (DIPA) was installed at Montclair State University
